Is success getting to its head? Maybe.... But a lot more needs to be done to ensure that this heritage restaurant continues surviving.

Good place for popiah - Hokkien style. It's all DIY so be prepared to get your hands dirty ! The popiah chili is absolutely spicy so be careful. The other highlight is the pig trotter noodles. I like the local feel to the place and the excellent foods

This restaurant is in the intercontinental hotel and we eat here every morning for breakfast. The selection is vast and changes daily. Going here is a huge treat for us. The staff is attentive and nice, notably chloe and sophie, though everyone has been exceptional.  The avocado toast is my daily go to and is delicious. There's something for everyone's palette which is rare in my family of 6.  I enjoy the local favorites while my children prefer the french toast and pancakes. Highly recommend!

Good lunch menu option, quite and perfect for lunch meetings during the week. Even better for weekend brunch. Great location and venue, ok service (not the most attentive). A bit overpriced--like everything else on the river......

address: 2 College Road Alumni Medical Centre Singapore 169850 Singapore
comment: One of the fish chunks Beehoon originators. Here to satisfy my fish soup cravings! My whole family came and ate:1) Fish Chunk Beehoon Soup - I like the meaty chunks of fish that's so fresh that it's not fishy at all. They have fish slice and fish head options but you can get fish slice anywhere but fish chunks are harder to come by. The soup is also flavourful without tasting fakely sweet. 2) Silver Fish Fried Rice - slightly too salty and very savoury indeed. My father-in-law was very happy with it.3) Fried Kuay Tiao - this is my daughter's favourite! It is served with a raw egg on top of a serving of dark sauced fried kuay tiao. Good dash of wok-hei.4) Kailan saute with garlic - simple dish that's done well. 5) Deep-fried Prawn-Paste Chicken - my hubby's favourite so it's a regular feature of our meals. Nice marinate without it being too over-powering of the prawn-paste taste. Beautifully fried to crispy goodness. Fingers-licking good.The small restaurant is tucked away in the Alumni house and it has ample parking usually, so it's a now popular place of mine.

address: 2 College Road Alumni Medical Centre Singapore 169850 Singapore
comment: This place been here for many years. It is famous for the fish soup noodle. It a Michelin place so I expected great food. Waitress was attentive and very good at up-selling. We were party of 3 and asked us to add 3 more dishes when we already ordered 4 including 2 proteins. The fish soup noodle came in a generous portion of fish. Thick slice and large slice. Unfortunately the soup seems fishy even as only few slices were fishy. I remember that it came with pork cracklings default but it does not. Only after finishing it I overheard some customers asking for it. The crispy bee hoon with seafood and egg was in general good. However some part of the bee hoon was tough which is because it was not fried enough. The sauce was good but the vegetables taste was slightly off. It seems ought as the place seem to have a fair bit of business so the vegetables should be fresh. Both the fried pork chop and prawn paste chickens were good but you can get almost similar quality from other restaurants. They were marinated enough to give them distinct taste. The chicken was also nice and crispy. For dessert we had the crispy Chinese pancake with red bean paste. The waitress cleared the table and provided fresh plates and chopsticks. The pancake was excellent, the skin was not too thick, the red paste was perfectly sweetened and fried to crispiness. Would give more stars if the fish soup and beee hoon dish was better.

address: 2 College Road Alumni Medical Centre Singapore 169850 Singapore
comment: This out of the way Chinese place is a tough to find gem. The interior is dated and the furniture cheap - but food is fantastic. The waiters were polite and helpful, bringing out the food quickly.And the food! The sliced fish soup had a delicious broth but light on actual fish. The beef hor fun was again great - a rich, delicious texture - but light on beef. The all-star was the Fried Chicken. Fantastic crispy fried exterior, soft and tender chicken inside. Coming back, I'd be tempted to just order the chicken. Came to $45 for two people (including a couple of soft drinks), which was very reasonable. If you're in the area and need somewhere to eat, this is a really reasonable option.

address: 2 College Road Alumni Medical Centre Singapore 169850 Singapore
comment: Ka Soh is known for its sliced fish bee hoon soup, especially its natural milky soup (from boiling the fish bones for hours) but somehow I think it is a bit over rated. There are probably other places with equally fresh and good fish slice bee hoon soup. But the prawn paste chicken wings are fabulous! I would go there for that. The chicken was served hot, fresh out of the fryer. Crispy skin with the taste of prawn paste, and moist juicy meat make a very good fried chicken indeed. The vegetables we had was equally good. Fresh crunchy greens simply stir fried with hint of butter. The day we went for dinner, it was sorely understaffed. There were only 3 waitresses on duty and the restaurant was running a full house. It was quite a wait for everything - from getting a table, to getting a chair (table was missing a chair), to being given a menu, to taking our orders. However food was served quite fast after the order was taken and we went straight to the counter to pay our bill as it would probably take a long time to wait at the table. Apparently there was an event that day and most of the staff were on duty there. The poor aunty waitress said they barely had time to breathe while coping with the dinner rush.

address: 2 College Road Alumni Medical Centre Singapore 169850 Singapore
comment: 3 words: PRAWN PASTE CHICKENWINGSKa-Soh is our place to go whenever we're tired of the usual things served at my workplace, but don't want to venture too far (this falls in the "can run back within 3 minutes if anything happens" category). It looks really dated (think almost-blank 4 white walls, no windows, depressing fluorescent lighting), and serves chinese restaurant-type food.But if you take the food out of the place it actually becomes quite awesome. Used to have it on takeaway on days that we were working overnight and those prawn paste chickens are THE ultimate comfort food when you've been running around like a madman trying to address all sorts of issues. The chicken is served hot, with a very crisp and flavorful skin and the meat is tender and juicy. I had like 5 pieces the last time I was here with my boss/teammates (and promptly got judged by the rest of my team).Budget probably about $7 - $20 ($7 for those on a diet/are only here for the chickenwings+rice+a drink and $20 for the gluttons).

address: 2 College Road Alumni Medical Centre Singapore 169850 Singapore
comment: I think of Ka-Soh as my big, warm, nourishing security blanket. At about $8, the sliced-fish bee hoon soup is likely the most expensive I've ever had, but hey, one gets what one pays for. There are no questions of whether you want milky or clear soup here because it's all milky--and the milkiness comes from the long brewing of fish bones. No milk here! I can feel the nourishment already. There is a choice between thick and thin fish slices (also fish head, but I don't like bones, so)--that really is a matter of personal preference, though I do like feeling I am getting more fish with the thin slices, and there's a nice "crunch" that isn't there with the thicker slices. The fish hor fun is also fantastic, with a great wok hei.Other than fishy things, Ka-Soh is also a proper zi char restaurant. Unfortunately, I'm never there with enough people to order more food, but eyeing other tables does make us envious...

address: 2 College Road Alumni Medical Centre Singapore 169850 Singapore
comment: Working literally upstairs of Ka-Soh has its benefits - there's the great Ka-Soh food, it's homely, aunty-ish vibe, and of course, staff discount. The restaurant itself is rather small, and gets crowded and noisy over lunch. Items not to be missed: sliced fish bee hoon soup - tip: get the fish chunk option. It's way better than the puny fish slices in the regular version. Prawn paste chicken - umami at its best. Hot, juicy, piquant fried chicken dipped into chill and then hungrily savored. Need I say more? Black bean beef horfun - tender beef slices, fragrant spring onion, flash fried with springy horfun. Wow. Just.. wow. The dessert menu is typical, though the deep fried yam is a thing of beauty - not cloyingly sweet, and encased in a light, crunch batter. It's not easy to get parking around Outram campus, and the great thing for Ka-Soh diners is that there's free parking within the Alumni Association building. While a little scary looking at night, it's pretty hard to deny the stateliness of this colonial establishment with it's pool and Owl Bar at the back.

I have been a couple of times for lunch, and more recently for dimsum breakfast. Lunch food is average. Dimsum service is excellent, with traditional carts and friendly aunties. The shrimp dumpling is great, and the buns are soft and tasty. Char siew buns and baked char siew are delicious too. I would go back for dimsum,  maybe not for lunch or dinner.

A distant relative suggested this place since my #1 criterion for a place to eat is there must be air-conditioning. I can't fault him since this is probably the only place that opens for dim sum at 8.30am. When he first said "Red Star", I was like "Red what??" I have never heard of Red Star despite I was born and raised in Singapore. Personally I believe if it was any good, my dad would have brought us there when we were kids. Notice I used the "was". I yelped the restaurant and had already prepped myself with the 1970s decor. I didn't expect it was so bad until I seen it with my own eyes. It was dingy and tacky. The location of this restaurant was not the easiest to find until you arrived at the building. Saw a sign indicating Red Star is located on the 7th floor. There was an elevator next to it, I was horrified when I entered it. When the elevator door opened on the 7th, I had no words. After following the signs, finally got into the restaurant. Yes, the decor was stuck in the 1970s, but I still can deal with it. After we got seated, the male staff asked what kind of tea we would like. His mannerism started from indifferent to rude.I looked around at the table setting in front of me. My plate was greasy. My bowl was dirty and so was the soup spoon. By this time the male staff came with a pot of tea and a metal bin of cups lying in there. He just left them on the table and walked away. And yes, the tea cup I pulled out from that metal bin was dirty too. Anyway, guess we would have to pour our own tea. Then came the highlight which was the dim sum.This restaurant has probably the worst dim sum I have ever eaten in Singapore. Honestly I never have awful dim sum in Singapore, this special award really goes to Red Star.Just to highlight a few items : 1) Siew Mai (pork dumpling) - F - it looked unappetizing, there was no flavor to it, the meat tasted weird2) Cheong Fun with BBQ pork - F - zero flavor, and the BBQ pork tasted weird too3) Egg tart - F - it was fresh from the oven, but the crust too dry and the custard part has no tasteAnother female staff was so rude when my relative asked if there was any egg tart. She basically said if it was ready, it would already be out.Rude service, awful food and overpriced for this kind of dim sum someone actually has the guts to serve to patrons.  I say those who like the food here do not know any better. It doesn't matter this place has been around for a very long time, things that are old are not necessarily good.And not to mention, the air conditioning was almost non existent here. Any self-respecting Cantonese will never give this place any star beyond 2. I chose a 1 or none.

This place - WOW. While dim sum here isn't the best you can get in Singapore, the entire dining experience here make up for it. To be honest, I've never heard of this place before until a group of friends talked about it and decided to bring me here for lunch last weekend.  Red Star is located on the 7th floor of a HDB flat (Block 54) within the Outram neighborhood. The restaurant is super retro - dim lighting, a center stage (for wedding singer or sort) and a huge main dining hall. The dining hall is filled with tables and chairs arranged in the most compact way to maximize the space, a common sight in any chinese restaurant.  We learnt that there are 2 ways to come up to the restaurant - one through the main door and another through the kitchen (back door). I think GOD knows that we're a curious bunch, the elevator we took lead us to the back entrance of the restaurant. We walked pass the kitchen, an oily walkway, through a few peculiar looking doors that says "RED STAR THIS WAY" before reaching the main dining hall. And then we saw the main entrance on the other side with people already queuing up trying to get a table during the peak brunch period. Lucky for us, another friend was there much earlier and already got a table when we reached. Service here is world class. Middle aged ladies with their headgear (like Emirates airlines) graciously push their cart to your table recommending and introducing different dim sums available for the day. They speak fluent cantonese and limited english but good enough to understand if you have any visitors or caucasian friend who cant understand mandarin or cantonese. I "interviewed" a couple of them and learned that they have been working here for the past 20+ years and take pride on their job. And with that I truly understand now that despite the average food, people still come back for its exceptional service as well as comfort food that's friendly to the wallet too.  Red Star is no where near any of the "finer" dim sum outlets we get in Takashimaya or 5 star hotels, but if you're looking for something different with a local touch, unpretentious, where you can talk and laugh as loud as you can then this place might be the right choice. I highly recommend this place.

Argh this place. I don't get it at all. There are horrendous queues for dim sum lunch because they don't take reservations, and we queued for about 20 mins on a public holiday Monday (2 of us).You don't always get what you want because you have to wait for the trolleys to roll past you, and then you flag em down and get what you want. Some of the trolley ladies don't holler out their wares, so you're gonna have to ask what they're hawking. I tried practically everything less the congee, and I have to say I am not impressed with the food. The rice rolls- argh. Too salty and dark a sauce. The siew Mai, forget it. The prawn dumplings had skin that was too thick and prawns within were unremarkable. The egg tarts had uneven levels of egg, and was really soso. I also tried the banana prawn fritter, and the skin was probably fried at the wrong temperature because it was oil-soaked yet not very crispy. The spring roll was dripping oil from it's too-thick skin. They also ruined my favorite dimsum item, the liu sha bao(custard bun), where  the bun was filled with a flowing custard that tasted of freezer burn! Other failures include the char siew bun, which had very little filling, was cold despite being in a steaming cart, and was awfully sweet. Just... weird. I don't know how this place survives. I don't care about the deco, I want my food. It cost about $50+ for two, but I feel it wasn't worth it at all. It was too expensive for what it was.

Familiar food. Familiar service. In an ever changing Singapore where every old thing make way for new, this little corner of history seems forgotten. I am not too young to find the place smell of old people, neither too old to find this place reminiscence.Food. It seems time essentially kept the food tasting great "just like old times"; both a compliment and a tinge of sarcasm. Compliment becos it still gives us a wonderful memory of the old HK dim sum taste like, and yet when the quality and evolving tastes has improved, this place has not. I am sure many of the customers have tasted better and more exquisite dim sum in HK and Singapore. But where can you find such reminiscence in this present day? Surely you can afford to pay for some historicity!Service. When compared to the other food places this has an army of people watching over our shoulders offering us the multitude of dim sum choices and the time to explain how each of them is special. Truely an experience only found in an old HK restaurant.The teacups came in a pot of hot water, just like old times. The pushers ( the people pushing the carts) is more varied; both old and young. It's not fair to keep those ladies working over 20 plus years thou some of them still do.New dishes. Apparently, they do add new varieties of dim sum, and have quite a number of "newer" deserts in their carts, those you can find everywhere else. They taste just like everywhere else so these I am not impressed! No historicity.Price. A bit pricey since we are paying for some historicity here, especially when you get to taste some of the old unchanged flavours dim sum in a old HK setting. Food is average. If you can get the ambiance and the historicity like me, those are the stars. If you want better food and a nicer modern ambiance with more cute looking or younger service people, leave the Q.Oh... The fragrance. I have to say something about the smell of food when I came thru the door. Suddenly I am reminded of the HK restaurant back in 1990 when I first met my HK in-laws! Yes. It was both pleasant and scary at the same time.

What an interesting place. I haven't seen these types of chairs for thirty years. The venue is very classic and sort of charming. The patrons makes me think this place won't exist in a couple decades ahem very old Is it overpriced ? Yeah basically. I could swear they are using canned mushrooms. Maybe if you come in a large party like most folks seem to, you will find the food packages more reasonably priced. Service is nice. No complaints there. Would I come back? I'm curious about the dim sum.

We made a reservation and went to this place last night ... only to find it completely empty! Apparently, it's only crowded during lunch time because of the Dim Sum. No reservations required for dinner. It was kinda awkward because it was a really huge restaurant (100 pax) and we had it all to ourselves. They stop serving Dim Sums after 3pm. We were very disappointed but made do with what we had. We didn't want to be rude and walk off since we were majority of the customers they had last night... so we ordered...The food 1. Fried bean curd & broccoli - LOVE it. The bean curd was so soft and silky. The dish was drizzle with sauce made out of crab meat and egg. 2. Prawns and cereal - LOVE it. Probably one of the best cereal prawns I had in awhile. The cereal was amazing. Can't quite put a finger to it but we ate every crumb. Another winning point was that the prawn was already de-shelled :) 3. Roasted chicken - Ok. A bit dry as most Chinese roast chicken are ... but its skin was crispy on the outside. 4. Crispy noodles & seafood - Ok. The noodles weren't very crispy by the time we had it. I would have ask for the sauce separately for this dish.  5. Omelette - Meh - Oily, greasy & not very tasty. Pass!Service - Super Fast! of course, there weren't many tables...except us.

The shrimp dumpling was the best of the bunch. The rest, very much the usual suspects you'd eat at a dim sum restaurant, was disappointing. The person most fond of char siew (BBQ pork) in the group only consumed 1/4 of the char siew bao (BBQ pork bun), claiming that the sauce tasted funny. The egg tart was cold. The pineapple buns actually had pieces of pineapples in them -- not that I would have minded it if the buns had tasted better. The kailan was drowned in some cold, nondescript, greasy goo.  As to the atmosphere, imagine an old Chinatown restaurant that is vast and dark, with nothing done to its deco since perhaps the 1970s. If that's your cup of tea, by all means, drop by, though don't expect to be wowed by the food, at least not the dim sum items.

It has a Hong Kong look and feel. When we were in Singapore we craved for dimsum so we went to the Red Star. It was ok. We loved the mango pudding dessert with milk though!!! Other dishes were ok, the thing that we did not like was that the dimsum was served cold because they stayed to long in the carts.

Much has been said about Red Star. It's one of those places that you either love, or hate. For me, if you want to have good dim sum, then you probably don't want to go to Red Star. Apart from the tacky 60's décor and how they still serve their dim sums in pushcarts, that's where the similarities end with restaurants in Hong Kong as I feel their dim sum is overpriced and severely lacking in quality.  However, if you're going there not for dim sum but to enjoy the wide variety of Cantonese dishes on offer, then it's a different story. Be sure to try the US roast duck, shark's fin with crab meat, fried garoupa in tomato sauce and their butter prawns, amongst some of their best offerings on the menu.

Not value for the $. Dishes were mediocre. The BBQ pork and roast pork skin were overpriced and not even that good at $10 a plate. Shrimp Chee cheong fun sauce was way too salty. Dessert 'Chee Ma hoo' was too diluted. Some of the other dishes : porridge OK - steam char siew Pao - char siew fillings too sweet, hsia long Pao was dried, bean curd wrapped seafood was OK, har kao standard. Only one item was good - chili wrapped long tau fu was excellent. $75 for 4 for bad to mediocre dim sum pricey. We get better dim sum in Dallas!

I'm sure many of you know of this place, since it has been established since quite a few decades ago, and has since been famous for their dim sum brunches. One thing I dislike about Red Star is how inconveniently it is located, and forces me to make a morning trek just to get to the restaurant! But all the better since it does make the food taste like victory! Be sure to arrive early since they don't take reservations for daily operations, and is one a first come first serve basis. There is usually a long queue that stretches all the way to the lift landing, so don't make the same mistake as I did, and arrive with a starving stomach, you won't be able to resist over ordering!  My staple dim sum dishes would be their fluffy egg tarts which are crisp around the edges and a soft pale yellow in the middle that looks healthy and non-artificial. The usual accompanying dishes would be siew mai, prawn dumplings with huge whole fresh prawns, and chicken feet if you can handle it! Their service really brings us back to the old days, where there are dozens of little Cantonese ladies pushing carts filled with goodies, going round table by table to serve you. If the food is not to your taste, at least it will be a morning filled with interesting conversations with these feisty ladies!

Red Star is something to be experienced. An experience to behold. It embodies the gaudy Chinese restaurants of your dreams (or nightmares). There's a certain charm to it.It's also an important piece of our food heritage. The people behind Red Star are also a part of the Heavenly Kings quartet, the four-some who redefined Chinese food in SIngapore (and some say Malaysia), by creating and inventing some of the dishes we now take for granted, like the yam ring and even the Chinese New Year yu sheng. It's a massive hall where people -- lots of people, and sometimes the occasional celebrity -- jostle for seats from the moment their doors open, especially on weekends. The stage that tells you you shouldn't attempt singing, on which so many of our parents' friends got married. The gaudy tablecloth. The dimsum trolleys.The food isn't great anymore.Especially considering the shift towards 'fine' dimsum, ordered off menus in restaurants far higher end than this.There's a tendency to automatically class this as "kopitiam dimsum" because it isn't the super refined Cantonese-style dimsum we've all gotten used to, and therefore say this isn't good.But it's still good. Especially considering how little you're paying for this, how authentically old school everything on the menu is, and what a funny, awesome, nostalgic experience it is to eat here each time. There was a period in 2010 or so when the food standard declined dramatically to the point of inedible, yes, but I'm glad to say that these old farts are back and their hargow and roast meats can out-heritage, if not out-class, all the wussy Crystal Jades and Imperial Treasures of the world.
Over hyped by the locals .... i guess mediocre food would taste good if you spent so long queuing for it

This restaurant used to be a popular place for Dim Sum amongst my parent's generation. As a kid, I enjoyed the fantastic delicacies they had. We stopped going there for a couple of years and my recent visit to Red Star was pretty disappointing. While the restaurant's age is showing through the dated decor, the old fashioned carts being pushed around by aunties serving Dim Sum still gives the place a nostalgic charm. The food, however, is no where near the standard of what it used to be. While the char siew sou is still pretty good with its buttery and flaky pastry with a moist, flavourful char siew centre, the rest of the Dim Sum we ordered did not impress. The standard of their pau (steamed buns) have dropped and the buns we got were rather stretchy and had a slight alkaline aftertaste. The siu mai just did not work for me. We ended up ordering congee to fill our tummies as we sort of lost faith in the dim sum there.

I have been to Red Star twice. It was recommended by a local friend.  They served more dishes on the cart on weekends. We anticipated good dim sum due to the long line. We were totally disappointed with the food and the service. It is a traditional Chinese restaurant with traditional CHINESE service - rude and no manners. The food was terrible. So, I thought the staff were busy on weekends therefore provided bad service. My parents were visiting, so I brought them there on a weekday and get a second opinion. My parents did not enjoy the food, every dish was lousy. There were very few choices to choose from. THe worse part was, the servers were very political. THey condemned each other. When I wanted to order some fried dishes, this server said, "It is not my department. You have to ask that lady. That lady is very grumpy. Don't order the fried stuff, they are not good." in Mandarin. I got to walk to that lady to get her to come to our table. She was not serving any customer yet she was impatient while my parents making choices. In conclusion, we never went back there since 7 months ago. I will not recommend to anyone.

Another interesting, hip place in Tiong Bahru, the kind that is frequented mostly by expats and local hipsters. It has the feel of an old canteen, reminding me of those desperately-trying-to-look-old, kitsch cantinas so popular in Mexico City, with tiled floors, posters on the walls and vintage marble tables, a bit crammed on the inside. To the untrusting observer, The Tiong Bahru Club may appear to be one of those places where form is more important than essence. However, the environment ultimately works and the place feels strangely authentic and inviting.The first interesting thing are the two different menus: East Asian and North Indian. Both of them contained snippets of information, kind of "explaining" the dishes. We were told to choose what kind of menu we wanted to have, so we chose the Indian menu (I'm always keen on Indian food). We had a very good, fragrant and spicy fish curry. Then I tried the masala chicken liver, which was spectacular. It was rich in flavour, while at the same time full of subtle surprises. I could say food tasted almost home-cooked, there was a special level of care involved. There's no way I couldn't love that.It must be hard to keep the balance of style and substance in a restaurant. My first impression of The Tiong Bahru Club was that of a place favouring the former. It is always good to be proven wrong. Here, style is no more than the background to a sense-appealing meal. I will surely come back.

It's Hip to Be Square! Here, There & Everywhere!TBC could be a 5-star hipstar hangout. It's got the trendy hipster location; it's got the style, swagger and streetcred. It's got the Singapore shophouse meets grandma's basement chillstar vibe.Instead it wallows in the 2-to-2-and-a-halfy range with lackadaisical lacklustreness.The service is the friendless math-olympics nerd who spent the weekend indoors doing times tables instead of outdoors chilling with chums.The food is the cowardly four-eyed flusher you bullied in first grade using their spiked hair liked a scrubbing brush in the lads lavatory.The brews are the too-cool-for-school kid who is trying too hard to be liked by everyone, and only marginally succeeding.The views are the pretty princess that makes attending class worth the while, and worth your smile.TBC coulda stood for The Best Club; Ten Beer ChillSpot; or To Be Continued (as in let's keep coming back). But instead it evokes Too Bland Chili; This Big Chode; or Tad Boring Chad.Huey got it wrong. Take it from me. TBC is a square, despite the hip!

Absolutely delicious Devil's Chicken Curry (at $16.80, a bit on the pricey side) really made my brunch! The sauce was bursting with flavor and spices, and the carrots, pork, and sausages were a fantastic accompaniment. A nice cup of chai went along with it superbly, and it was served with just the right amount of rice. I'm lactose intolerant, and it was lovely to find Indian in Singapore without ghee (clarified butter) so I could eat it! My friend's biryani was delicious too: light and fluffy, tasting of gardens.The outdoor seating was the perfect blend of the aircon from inside and the heat of the sidewalk, with people watching and a good breeze. Decor is cute and appealing - a blend of the club and the chaiwallah stand which both supply the place. The issue was that our server was quite obviously completely new and pretty inept (sorry, buddy, but you were.) He said they offered chai by the pot and let us order some - by the pot - but they only serve it by the glass, as the server who brought it over explained after our mystified glances at the solitary cup. He also said they were offering their Bento Box special but when I tried to order it, turned out that's only available on weekdays. Study your menus and learn your stuff, servers, so that your service can match with your fine establishment's prices.

The overall look and feel of this venue is ok, that's why I still give 2 stars.The foods are overpriced compared to the quality offered. I took a cappuccino and a Cheese beef burger (22$ ++)The cappuccino is too milky, and when it was served, I don't feel like having ordered a real cappuccino (4 or 4.5 $ ++, see my photo). The minced beef in the hamburger was too salty.When I asked for ketchup, they give you ketchup in small package. I asked mustard twice, because the first time they did not say they don't have mustard, the second time they kind of simulate like they are looking for it then announce that they don't have mustard. Can't they say directly that they dont have if they already know...?About the bread, it seemed to me that they are using first price quality. The burger was not worth 22$

A new upmarket restaurant has opened in Tiong Bahru! I know.. What's new right? Located at the corner of Eng Hoon St. And Seng Poh road, we've seen this place transform from an old coffee shop (our favourite Loo's Hainanese curry rice used to be here) transform into this upmarket eatery. At first glance, this place looked like just another upmarket, snooty diner, filled with expats, yuppies and a certain breed of Singaporean females that have a certain preference for guys I should not name. Anyway... What got us trying this place was the nostalgic feel and the fact that it did not serve the usual eggs Benedict, breakfast sets, waffles or pancakes, and they certainly didn't promote themselves as the next big coffee joint with magical beans from the bottom of the Amazon River. Instead, what this place specializes in is... Indian food and chai!! Surprise surprise! Well.. I guess it made sense considering that the Brits and the Indians / Sikhs have long had a history together. Anyway... I'm a sucker for indian food so this place, despite how hard I tried to say no, still got the better of me. They have 2 sets of menus here, an Asian menu, with fried rice and soto Ayam and an Indian menu. We decided to go for a Murgh Dum Briyani, my favourite Palek Paneer,a Masala Chicken Liver and what better way to wash down our food than with a nice pot of Himalayan Sikkih tea.First came the Briyani. A good sharing portion that could easily feed 2-3 pax. The rice was wonderfully fragrant with the spices and flavours beautifully infused in and the chicken, despite being the breast, was tender and oh-so-flavourful. So good in fact that it just might be one of the best Briyani's I've had in a while. Next was the Masala Chicken liver. Now this dish was the star of our lunch. It is literally to die for! The liver was nice and tender and the sauce, with all its onions and spices was amazing. Every bite was a dream and this dish is enough to bring us back for more. Finally the Paneer, my personal favourite. The sauce was nice and smooth without the spinach being over powering while the cheese was smooth and "bouncy". Only thing it could do with was a little more salt, otherwise it was another very good dish. The tea itself was nice and fragrant and proof that chaitime, the guys behind this restaurant, know their teas. Overall, it was s wonderful experience and the only reason this place didn't get a 5 is down to a few simple factors. A) indoor searing was a little tight, with most 4 pax tables nearly touching each other and effectively becoming a 3 top. B) service was slow as well, with the 2 waiters clearly being inexperienced and frankly a little lost most of the time. C) food did take a little longer than it should, with U.S. almost finishing our Briyani by the time the paneer came. D) the prices. A little on the strap side at around $20-$25 per pax for an Indian meal. Overall, I love how they kept some of the coffee shop's elements while updating it, leaving a nice nostalgic feel, down to the music choice. We'll definitely be back for more!

My review will be in line with most of the other ones. This place is average. Prices are expensive because of the locations but not because of the food taste which is average and overpriced. The manager and staff is nice but that's it. Another Tiong Bahru overpriced place that is most likely replacing a good ole Chinese joint.
Is it an eating place? A bar? Cafe? For a drinking place it's ok. I love the outdoor seating but the lights are too bright and the selection is quite limited. Didn't try the food.

On a hot Saturday afternoon, this place caught our attention because it was an old kopitiam refurbished to a modern day pub restaurant. We were just looking to quench our thirst. Seeing that Chaiholics was serving their tea specialties, we decided to give the chai a go. Firstly, I thought the teas were overpriced. $6.50 excluding taxes. But nonetheless we went for it. If the tea was good, no issues paying. But the tea was a big disappointment. Mainly that it tasted so watered down.  Additionally the spoons looked quite stained and dirty. We didn't dare use them. Such a shame.

The food was excellent as was the service. Personally greeted and recommendations were made for strawberry lassi. It was very refreshing for a hot Saturday afternoon. We ordered the lamb biryani and murg tikka. That may be too much food for the two of us but it was so delicious, we finished it all. It is made to authentic north Indian standard, very difficult to come by here in Singapore. Loved the food very much! The ambience is great too. There are always people eating there regardless of what time of the day I go past it. Especially at night. It is however slightly pricey, at about $20-25 an entrée and $6-8 for a drink. Total of about $30-35 per person. I'll definitely be going back for more.

Kinda cool vibe indoor outdoor and not too hot. Not familiar with the vibe which I guess is like an old timey coffee shop or harkens back to colonial times. Am always uncomfortable with that bc yeah it might've seemed cool but was not cool for the majority of those not in the elite. Anyhow it was cool enough in the evening inside and they had mixed chairs and cool wood floor etc. just be careful if ur inside and then you moved your chair back and one leg falls off the elevated floor and u could fall and hit ur head. The food was actually pretty good - the Indian food only. We had chicken not the spicy one and it was juicy and citrusy and delicious. Also had the Dahl and the baigan bartha and naan and plain rice and one more thing. But it was all tasty and very spicy but good. The service was meh. I asked for ginger ale and they said no we don't have it. I pointed out on the menu where it was listed. Was advised they don't have it anymore. Asked what on this list they had. They have juice and coke. There were five more things listed. Ok I'll just have water. Have to flag them down if you want anything so they don't check back. But at least they don't bother you and let u stay to chat. They're not clearing ur plates as soon as ur done which was my experience in most other restaurants in Singapore.

If I could give it no stars I would. I went here on a friend's recommendation but either the management has changed or they were having a really bad night. The service was so bad it was comical. I don't see how any restaurant can charge prices like this when they offer such poor or no service. The menu prices were quite expensive.We struggled to get drinks. One waiter barely spoke English and when we did finally manage to order he would take an order  from 1 out of 7 people and disappear. We'd try to call the waiter back and he would take another order but forget half of the drinks. So we had to send our son to the bar to remind him. Then they ran out of beer. There was wine on the table but noone knew how much it cost.The food we had was OK but nothing to rave about. we only got a few entrees and this was only because my husband ordered them earlier as he had arrived 1/2 hour before  us. We had to get up and get our own plates as the waiters forgot.  After we had been in restaurant for 1.5 hrs we asked how our food was going and discovered the order had not been put through. The waiters were inept. We left as we'd run out of patience by then and everyone was grumpy.What was supposed to be a special birthday dinner was a disaster and I had 3 tired hungry children you feed at 9.30 pm.I've had better service in a hawker market for a fraction of the price!

Understand why reviews continue to become lower. An attractive place that wants to portray itself as a "neighborhood" facility. In reality, however, the prices mirror the tourist spots on Orchard. S$12 for a small bottle of Tiger beer. Really? Seriously? It goes down hill from there. Won't return.

2 of us decided to walk there after coming back from the fantastic LeonardoDaVinci'sBlueprints exh on the final Saturday of 2014. It was pouring heavily but fortunately, the place was just 10mins' walk from apt. Was enticed by the 3for2pints of draft HoffbrauDunkel and had those with tandoori roll, sambal eggplant and lotsa complimentary groundnuts. Everything was tasty and ended up staying until they closed shop@10:30pm.
Distinctly average. Very disappointing considering the fact that everything else in this area, has really good food and service.

rest_name: Koo Kee Yong Tow Foo Mee
address: Blk 32 New Market Road #01-1114 Singapore 050032 Singapore
comment: Ok, this review is for this hawker center, not this particular one. Food here is authentic, old world Sg and prices are good. H.mee fkt, mee rebus, porridge, chicken rice, duck, pork belly. My fav area to eat in sg.

Reached out to a local friend when I knew we would be heading back to Sing for another trip and he suggested we check out No 3 Crab Delicacy for chili crab.  Since this was going to be a short trip, we planned on having a late lunch here only to realize they close in the afternoon right before dinner.  Not exactly sure their hours but be warned to check their hours before making the trek out to this place.  Also, they are now located on the ground floor of the Link hotel and not on Outram Road (basically around the block).  We were the first patrons of the night and the restaurant did seem a bit dead as we were eating.  Not sure if it was just an off night or if business just wasn't good anymore.  I was urged to try the rajak chicken along with their chili crab.  Wasn't sure what to expect with the rajak chicken but it was pretty tasty.  A perfectly fried thigh of chicken was topped with a sweet/sour/savory sauce with cucumber and some sort of fruit on top.  Wasn't a big fan of the sauce as the initial bite did have a strong fish sauce flavor but the more I ate, the more I ended up enjoying it.  The crab here was also pretty good just wished the sauce had a bit more kick to it.  You will definitely need to order man tou or some sort of noodles to truly enjoy the chili crab sauce.Overall a decent meal that it wasn't  exactly Hawker food stall prices.  A nice local restaurant but the wife did say the sauce for the chili crab was slightly different than from what she remembers.  There are tons of restaurants that specialize in chili crab so not sure I'll be back any time soon.

All crab lovers... you will love this place.It is not cheap however, and can easily come up to $50-$60 per person. Get the crab bee hoon. No finger bowls but they have paper napkins.Sometimes I wonder how honest they are about the weight of the crabs. I wish I could bring a weight scale and weight the crabs myself. Seems like a couple of famous people have visited this place too.

It's been ages since I visited No. 3 Crab Delicacy Seafood Restaurant so I was thrilled to be able to return for a fix last evening. As we were planning to visit another restaurant after this, we only ordered 2 dishes - both of which are my favourite ones here. We started the meal with a large plate of Drunken Cockles (S$20 / US$14.67). The juicy raw  cockles had been cured in soy sauce, Chinese wine, garlic and topped with some fresh chili padi (Thai chili). The copious amount of minced garlic imparted a lovely flavour to the dish but doesn't make for a good dish to indulge in if you're on a first date. Another signature dish here is the Curry Crab in Claypot. Even though it's been a long time since I ate here, the rich, creamy curry gravy was as good as I remembered. The flavourful gravy was a perfect complement to the smooth strands of boiled Beehoon (rice vermicelli). The medium-sized Sri Lankan Crab was succulent and so big, it was almost spilling out of the claypot! The Crab dish set us back by S$ 75.40 (US$ 55.28) before 7% GST & 10% service charge. The beehoon is priced at $5 (US$ 3.67) per plate, which though pricey is worth a splurge to be able to fully appreciate the flavourful curry gravy. If you stop by here and have a decent tolerance for spice, do order the Drunken Cockles and Sri Lankan Crab Curry.

I went to Singapore because I wanted to eat hainan chicken rice and CHILI CRAB!!This restaurant wasn't too far from the hotel so we walked here.Ordered chili crab, bun tou, fried crispy baby squid, sambal slipper lobster, veggies and clams.My favorite dish was the crispy baby squid.  Omgosh it was so good I wanted to eat the whole plate by myself.  I am not a fan of clams but I like the clams from this place.The other dishes (including chili crab) were not that good.3 stars!!

I have been here 4-6 times in last 3 years.  Each time a friend from overseas comes to visit and wants to try the famous Singaporean chili crab, I take them here.  Why?  This place has the best chili crab in entire Singapore.  No Signboard?  Jumbo?  Seriously?I have been to Jumbo three times and No Signboard twice and they can't stack up against this place and their buns...mmm...and crab meat fried rice...and to make things even better, a lot cheaper than those over-priced two: No Signboard and Jumbo. And since they do use live crabs, the meat doesn't stick to the shell (I heard this somewhere whether it's true or not) and crabs are big!Anyway, I love this place and I will continue to come here each time I have guests visiting

Come here for MASSIVE crabs from Sri Lanka..... Personally I prefer them as they are much easier to consume; usually crab is a 90% work and 10% actually eating for me. Sauces were excellent; we had the chili and butter variety. For both the sauces were savory and tasty with crab or simply on rice. Plenty of other nice dishes as well; I liked everything they put in front of me!Great for groups.... Plenty of large round tables.Simple décor, fine service.Good value, we paid about $45/person for 2 HUGE crabs, plenty of entrees and drinks.  Probably ordered too much as we had leftovers.....Really enjoyed the meal here, so far my favorite crab in Singapore! Would definitely come back.

It is was my first visit to Singapore and was told about their famous Chili Crab.  I was very impressed with 3- Crab Delicacy's menu and food preparation. Their Chili Crab is excellent.  It is located along Tiong Bahru where there are many attractive restaurants next to it. The female owner had mentioned that they had just moved to Tiong Bahru a month ago.  The cost for the Chili Crab runs around $48 but was worth every cent.

Forget those tourist traps like Lau Pa Sat or Newton Circus - this is THE place to go for huge crabs. I'm saying like the size of your face huge. Hidden away on a side street by Outram, it's easy to miss this restaurant among the various other zhi char stores nearby, so do come prepared with directions in hand. Open all the way from 11.30am to 11.30pm, many old regulars living in the area drop by for late night indulgences in their signature crab dishes, and I've seen many order crab to go as well. Their top selling dish is obviously the chilli crab, but if you're tired of the usual like me, do try their Butter Crab. It's served drenched in a thick creamy butter sauce, and lightly seasoned with crushed garlic for a plate of steaming fresh delicious seafood. The sauce is also lighter than the spicy chilli or heavy black pepper taste, so it's easier to allow the natural freshness of the crab to be picked up by your palette. This means you can actually appreciate the crab meat and not just the sauces. Their fried Man Tou (buns) are no joke either, dig in while they're hot to enjoy the crispy brown surface and steaming white insides. Dipping it in any of the sauces from the crab dishes just makes them a hundred times better! Price can range from about $30 to $50 per person if a large group for 4 - 6 are sharing 2 crabs, which is definitely more than enough!

Couldn't wait to go back after first visits in 2013....still the same delicious ginormous crabs prepared to order with various sauces and spiced to your specifications. Great with the little buns and the spinach side dish. A little bit off the beaten path for tourists so you will be among mainly locals. Plan on about $50 per person....worth it!
Not very good crab (tried black pepper and chili). Not a great price. Very weird ambiance (or lack thereof).

Went to this place because it was recommended by a website.  Big mistake.  There were lots of pieces of shell in the chili and the food was not worth the cost.  At the end of the meal, we were charged 50 cents for each napkin that we used and for "peanuts" that we did not order.  This restaurant seems to be a rip off.
We are crab eater and instantly knew the crab was not fresh.  I wanted to buy my parents a good dinner, but my mom was disappointed that I spent the money.

Robertson Quay is undergoing some serious revival with new hotels and changes in the food scene along the river. A homegrown favorite SPRMRKT has expanded and set up shop at the Singapore Tyler Print Institute (STPI) Creative Workshop & Gallery. I've walked past several times but only noticed their bistro concept SPRMRKT Daily. Little did i know that their Kitchen & Bar, which serves refined European food, is tucked away upstairs through a side stairway.The spot is absolutely gorgeous in the day with expansive views of the idyllic riverside. Lunch sets are offered, starting from $30, served with coffee or tea. They have also started their weekend brunches and we say grab a table now!For lunch, start with a simple but wholesome Brussels & Roots with a honey clove dressing. The vegetables are simply steamed- golden baby beetroots and baby turnips along with the Australian Brussels sprouts. The garden of greens is flavored with pops of umami from the slow-baked tomatoes seasoned with thyme, garlic, sea salt and olive oil.For lunch, go for a lighter Pan-Roasted Chilean Sea Bass. The fish is seared and basted with butter, then finished in the oven with a simple touch of salt, pepper, and lemon juice. A refreshing ratatouille adds a juicy crunch to the mix. We agreed with the chicken stock flavored polenta which was rich and velvety with some Parmesan sharpness.For dinner, the Firefly Squid ($24) surprised us with a bacon-like smokiness in the meatless cauliflower puree. I have no idea how but i'd take all the cauliflower puree as a guiltless replacement. The special firefly squid from Japan is intensely flavored, having been marinated overnight in soya sauce, sake, mirin and brown sugar. Definitely order the Octopus & Prawn ($24). This has to be one of the best (if not the best) Spanish octopus i've eaten this year. The octopus is simmered whole with mirepoix and other spices and white wine for 2 - 3 hours before grilling on a plancha. The crispy skin and that tender flesh were unforgettable.I didn't like the Fjord Trout ($19). I'm not sure if it's due to the way it's cooked- mi cuit style, sous vide with salt, but the flesh was mushy and powdery. The flavor was great, just not the texture. Fresh pasta are a must these days. If you like something really meaty, the Malbec Oxtail Pasta ($32) with a smoky Scamorza will satisfy. The oxtail is braised with Malbec (my favorite wine) to impart that berries, plum, and chocolate flavor. Perfect comfort food. Can i have another glass of Malbec to go with this please?A favorite at SPRMKT is the Smoked Lobster Tail ($42) which features a cold smoked and then seared Maine lobster with toasted garlic panko bread crumbs and a Mac n Cheese. The cheese sauce is a lot lighter than usual as they have added pumpkin puree to the Emmental, aged Parmesan, and Mozzarella mix. I absolutely love the Twice Cooked Chicken Roulade ($28). I've not had a chicken so good in a while. The juicy chicken thigh is brined overnight and then rolled with a creamy spinach and mushroom duxelle, before being cooked sous vide and then shallow fried for that amazing Peking-duck-like crispy skin. It's great on its own, with its own jus, or with the amazing curry cauliflower puree (seriously they are so good with their cauliflowers). I can go on forever about the other tender juicy red that is the Stockyard Côte de Boeuf ($94). This 200 days grain-fed 600g Australian bone-in beef ribs is good for 2. The ribs are first coated with a house made Creole spice rub before being seared and roasted. Drizzle a little of that beef jus made with roasted bones, red wine, tomatoes, and veal jus for some tart umami. The meat is served with mixed mushrooms, roasted rosemary tomatoes and vine-ripened tomatoes. Perfect date meal!End your meal with a fragrant and light Earl Grey Creme Brûlée ($16) scented with a lemon lavender streusel base and fresh seasonal fruits.For something rich and earthy, the Three Beet Chocolate Lava Cake ($18) delighted us with the medley of textures created with the versatile root. Of course, we cannot resist a 70% Valrhona dark chocolate lava cake. I wouldn't be surprised to see more of this beetroot and raspberry sorbet on the market. I'm already seeing a lot of beetroot on the menu of many noteworthy restaurants.

We stopped for a quick lunch - very nice ambience next to the riverside. While the chicken Milanese wrap was good, the pan seared salmon was just average..if you want a late lunch/brunch with a good view, you may consider this..
Was there for breakfast. Good food, nice variety. Great attentive service. First time, since they just opened. But will def be back for more.

This place is at one of the locales in the Tyler Print Institute building at Robertson Quay. At first is a bit confusing, the name suggests a market, and they do sell a few (overpriced) fruits and vegetables, but it can also appear as a bakery, cafe, restaurant, takeaway or souvenir store. They seem to have a bit of everything.As a restaurant they have few tables outside where they serve an interesting menu. Ambitious might be the proper word to describe it. They have common dishes, mostly Western, but made with a slight, almost imperceptible, twist, mainly done by adding a touch of a different flavour, which lifts the plate. For example, the sweet potato fries come with a well-balanced curry mayonnaise. More importantly, the food I've had there a couple of times is done with care and precision. Prices seem rather high, but portions are on the generous side, so I think they're fair (it's Robertson Quay anyway). Burgers are big and delicious, and pasta is served in more than enough amounts. Mainstream beers are expensive at 10++ for a miserable half pint, but they have good craft beers at the same price for a bottle. Coffee is not bad, but nothing to rave about. Cakes are tasty, worth trying. An important thing is they make an effort in offering more local products rather than imports, maybe they could make that more explicit.Inside the shop, there are three tables that serve as a cafe, and there's a shelf that showcases souvenirs of the interesting kind, I'm talking about Singlish "dictionaries" and Teochew recipe books instead of Merlion keychains. While these quirky souvenirs are quickly becoming mainstream, they also sell books by Math Paper Press, which are truly good local gifts.SPRMKT has a little bit of many different things and, sometimes, it's not quite clear what to expect. It is, after all, a place to have a nice dining experience and find some amusing local products. It is worth a try, the food is better than it would seem.

Food was amazing. We ordered the haloumi (goat cheese), giouvetsi (beef cheek with pasta), Biftekia (beef patty with roasted tomatoes and fries) and the Greek yoghurt and Greek donuts - shared across 3 people.They were all splendid. And the atmosphere was perfect on a nice weekday night.We will definitely return.

Good service and nice atmosphere. Food was delicious, but a little sour for my personal taste. Highly recommend the tzatziki and horiatiki (greek salad). The keftedes melitzanas were also good, but the fried eggplant balls were quite heavy.

Good Greek food spot on Amoy Street - would recommend the seafood selection here from fish to octopus - everything is very fresh. The pita / hummus is ok as well. Very good wine as wellNice / Santorini-like ambiance. Quite a popular lunch spot so would recommend making a reservation

The food from start to finish was divine, fresh and just the simplest but most delicious.  We started on dips and the Greek rice packets.  One of the best I have had.  The grilled octopus was out of this world.  You can taste the char, the sea and the texture all at once.  We has the sea bream which was prepared in the simplest format and you can taste how fresh it was.  The Baklava was fantastic and we wish we could have tried the others too.Definitely go in a group as you can order more to try and taste.  Will go back for sure.  Highly recommended.  Best Greek in Singapore.  Service is a little hit and miss but food is that good everything else can be excused!

I visited Alati with a friend yesterday for dinner, it's a restaurant with beautiful white and blue Santorini-like interior design, great ambience for couples, friends and families to dine. The food is impeccable, we ordered the spinach pie, fava, grilled Greek octopus, lamp chop and the grilled seabream. I especially love the spinach pie and grilled seabream. Their seafood is displayed on a table in front of the entrance, you can see them when you walk into the restaurant, they are very fresh indeed. My friend and i enjoyed our dinner very much, and would definitely love to come back again soon.

Decided to try this place out after we read about it on Yahoo. We started with the eggplant dip and pita, followed by the grilled octopus, Greek salad, and salt-baked sea bream. I've never been to Greece before, so I can't comment on the authenticity. However, we really enjoyed everything we ordered. The salad was ridiculously fresh with a good balance of cheese, capers, olive oil, and lemon. The grilled octopus was also very tender and flavorful. The fish was nice but a little on the dry side. We were tempted to try the fried Greek donuts and were glad we did. The six puffy yeast balls came with a scoop of vanilla ice cream and chocolate syrup and honey for dipping. It was not overly sweet or greasy. The only reason I'm not giving this place five stars is because the service was not as personable or friendly as one would expect for a typical cosy, charming establishment like this.
We tried the Souvlaki and the Keftedes. Both dishes were excellent. The ambience and decor brings greek holiday feeling to Singapore. Very friendly service!

Great Greek Mediterranean food!  Super Fresh fish.  Very hefty portions.  We shared the grilled Seabass.  And Greek salad.  Olive oil used was awesome.  Chef came out and sought feedback.  He highly recommended the salt encrusted cooking method.  Definitely will try next visit.
We felt like eating in a Greek friend's fancy living room. The interior was chic yet at the same time cozy. Food was very good. Especially the mains. Would recommend the lamb chops and mousakka.

Amazing, authentic Greek food. The place is nicely done up in the ever popular blue & white combination. Between 2 of us,  we had a set dinner (Greek salad, prawns, grilled fish and walnut cake) with a separate portion of the chicken souvalaki. The food was delicious and portion sizes good for sharing. We especially loved the Greek salad, prawns, chicken and cake. Their Greek olive oil is also the real deal Infact this was possibly the best and most authentic Greek walnut cake we have had in Singapore, with just a hint of cinnamon! Will definitely be back for more.

This place had amazing Dim Sum, we didn't order much else as that is what we were craving.Service was friendly with a smile and they were happy to answer any questions we had on the food.Would love to come back and try the buffet order off the menu. Sounds weird but still want to test it out.

Three stars for the staff services. We ate the Chinese buffet dinner. The foods are nothing wow about. They are edible to fill the stomach. The fried fish, fried pineapple rice, soy sauce noodle, a lots of shrimps, steam fish, roast porks, duck meats, pork ribs, etc. As mentioned earlier edible nothing to specially mentioned about their flavor, aroma. I do like the mango sago and jelly desserts. Not too sweet.

Came here twice. Once on a weekday, the other a weekend. There was an April only promotion - 50% off for 4 pax.My first visit, weekday lunch starts at 11am. So there were 3 of us and the promotion would not apply to us unless we bought a 4th pax and we would enjoy the 50%. The usual price was $48++ per person. And so we did as recommended by the manager.Peach Garden is located in the Amara Hotel in the Havelock area.. Parking here can be pricey if you come on a weekday. We parked some distance away off Chin Swee Road, in the residential area and took a short walk to the hotel.Once we sat down, we were promptly attended to. We ordered our tea and took a look at the menu. The promotion menu is on a piece of print out where one would be required to mark what we wanted.Our first dish was the deep fried Soon Hock (Grouper). The dish was excellent. Every part of the fish was edible, even the tail because it was so crispySoup: we ordered a mix of clear sharks fin broth & thicker version. Both were tastyAbalone & wasabi. This turned out a little disappointing. The salad was rather bland. There wasn't a key item for the eyes to feast on therefore killed the dish for me.Fried shrimp. Slightly oily but tasted great. Would've preferred lighter/less batterSpinach, tri-egg in broth. This dish is a must have.On my second visit being a weekend, there were 2-round seating, one being 11am, the other being 1pm. Therefore be aware you cannot sit leisurely for lunch.The menu had fewer soup items, and a few additional items. This time, the manager told me that the Soon Hock is not available. This was a huge disappointment because this time, we brought our grandmother who loves fish. And we had to order other fish dish.This time, everything was salty. The saltiest item we ordered was the spinach noodle in Mapo Tofu sauce. We returned it. What we ordered that we did not the other day were Indonesian curry shrimp. The shrimps were fresh. Flesh was tender. Curry base was tasty. Would've loved it better if some yew tiao were provided to soak up the sauce.Steamed PaTing fish, slightly fishy, but still quite good. sauce it was sitting in was good with rice.Herbal shrimp. This was so good, we each drank up all the herbal soup that the shrimps were sitting in.Deep fried fish skin. It was good but was a little soft by the time the skins were served.I would definitely come back again but will only do it when there's a promotion. Otherwise, it's just too expensive.

Peach Garden 30% off Dim Sum.The dim sum menu items on the menu has only 17 varieties. Most of the normal dim sum was on it. The most expensive item is the shark fin dumpling with abalone being S$20 per bowl. The rest of the items starts from S$5.80 onwards.Entrance from the car park goes directly into the dinning area. You have to make your way to the front to meet the maitre'd. Service after that was fast. The waitress asked which tea would we like but actually she only had one type, so why bother to asking? Chances of someone ordering the tea she carries is like 1 in 70 due to the number of tea combo there are. There were numerous occasions that the waitress brought us the wrong order, sure the restaurant was crowded but not full.We ordered the normal stuff, prawn dumplings, meat dumplings, chicken legs, steam pork rib, various buns, century egg and pork porridge, fried carrot cake and the $20 shark fin dumpling. Unfortunately the shark fin dumpling was not that good and does not worth the $20. The pork ribs was lean and so after steaming, it was really tough. The various prawn and meat dumplings was average. The char siew pow was above average and was the only item worth ordering. The century egg and lean pork porridge was rather expensive as it was like 7 spoons of porridge only. The carrot cake was also nice but it was $18 and comes with prawns.Overall the food is just average and it was rather expensive But hey this is a after all an hotel restaurant.

OVERPRICED food. they jacked up the prices again recently. also, they chase you out of the restaurant 1 hour into your dining and then tell you that you must place your last order.absolutely crap. i will NEVER EVER GO TO PEACH GARDEN AGAIN.

Amazing dinner buffet deal in Singapore where you pay around 300 hkd ( ask for the year round buy one get one free) for unlimited amount of Chinese food. It's one of those buffet places where you order from the menu. Food quality is great and the restaurant is clean with nice table cloth. It's a steal for the quality and price .

We came here for weekend dinner. service was crappy, the waitress asked if we made our reservation and what time slot was given to us?? we didn't receive any specific 'slot', as our booking was at 730pm, but we arrived earlier at 7pm. She then went on saying that if we made the booking over the phone, the person would have told us about our timing to eat - which we weren't given at all?? after that she went and came back and said ok, we could eat and our last order was till 915pm. Really strange service, and food took awhile to come. Food was meh. We paid total for 6 pax, per person at around $30++ after the 'promotion'. I think we could have had better quality food at a regular zi char store with much tastier food. The worst we had was the 'char siew with bones'. Seriously? Nope. Never again.

address: 392 Havelock Road Grand Copthorne Waterfront Hotel lobby Singapore 169663 Singapore
comment: One of my relatives decided to try here as other places that she wanted to try were fully booked for lunch.Passed by Grand Copthorne hotel quite frequently and wondered what was the inside. And yes, I was thrilled when I heard that we are going to try out the buffet here. On the lift, it has quite a few advertisements about the Laksa and some other foods but I did not really sink that in until I came to this cafe.Open concept dining - score. This so called cafe has also plenty of seats. Located on the 1st floor, you wouldn't probably miss this place. Was served by the waitress promptly to our seats. Like any other buffet style, I know that we can walk around and see the food first before getting the food. As a foodie, I took pictures of foods as well as the assigned chefs and update it on Yelp first. I started at the end corner where the international chef was serving ham and turkey. Got myself a honey baked ham. And there was other toppings for the turkey but I placed it on my ham instead. Took a couple of food types in small portions there and started circling the other stalls. I also took a piece of scallop. Like the ham and the scallop. Ham was soft and tasty while scallop has ingredients on it as well which produced flavorful taste.Next stall I went to was the Laksa store. After seeing the advertisement on the way to the buffet area, I was somehow imagining the taste and flavor just by looking at the ad. Yes yes!! My imagination and my tastebuds matched. A must try dish if you pop by here.Next station was the sushi station. Got myself quite colorful sushis (not sure about the names) but the difference are the ingredients. There was a sushi master cutting sashimi at that area too. Didn't really get it as I wanted to taste other foods. Sushi's rice wasn't well done and not as fresh as the seafood section.Next stop, soup station - clam chowder and piece of french baguette. Quite disappointed with the cold soup and cold french baguette. Was expecting it to be warm.Last of all, dessert! I tried most of the dessert for the day. There are two kinds of shots - raspberry and chocolate. Loved the raspberry one. The chocolate was too thick and I was expecting it to be like a chocolate mousse in the cup. The log cakes - chocolate: bitter and need to acquire the taste before indulging in more, fruity flavored: passionfruit mousse with shredded coconut was the perfect combination of all. Tried the raspberry mousse cake. Loved the texture and sour sweet taste in it. Ginger creme brûlée sounds weird but it was good but please avoid strawberry as it had caramel on it. Overall, I am very satisfied with the dessert section. There were ice creams with cones too at this dessert corner but was too full to gulp into more delicacies.Service was excellent - servers cleared the plate as soon as I placed my plate aside. Was quick in serving water when asked too. Overall, I am very satisfied with the buffet style in this cafe. Do try it when you are in the area!

address: 392 Havelock Road Grand Copthorne Waterfront Hotel lobby Singapore 169663 Singapore
comment: A giant 15 feet Christmas Tree greeted me when I stepped into the lobby. Making a detour around it, I spotted a familiar figure--Mr Santa--resting happily in the goodie house and surrounded by his old friends, Mr and Mrs Gingerbread Men. The cheery festive spirits at Grand Waterfront Copthorne Waterfront were highly infectious and they definitely pumped up my appetite to indulge in the Yuletide treats at Cafe Brio's. Here are FIVE REASONS why this is a great location to wine, dine and be merry!Reason No.1:SALADS I know most people would naturally dive straight into the oysters and sashimi but it would be a grave strategic error NOT giving their salads a chance. One never look at buffet salads the same way again after trying the tasty offerings such as juicy mushroom salad, fresh corns with lentil beans and even a "heart-shaped" Seafood salad constructed with lots of cured salmon cubes and cherry tomatoes for that bit of tart balance. And the deeply savoury Norwegion Smoked Salmon with horseradish cream? Yes, they are my salads too. Reason No. 2: LIVE STATIONWith hotels upping their ante to dish up fresh hot food ala minute, live stations are no longer a novel concept. But where in Singapore can one possibly have Australian meatballs at the Live Station?  And there's the famed superb Super Laksa here too. The fragrance of the coconut milk permeates the potent broth which is the key that makes it an arduous task to leave any drip behind. It must be a lot of hard work for the one-man chef who is tending the station; one hand busy boiling the noodles and the other hand cooking the tomato sauce. But fret not as the quality is highly assured. Reason No. 3: MEATSBuffet is always a game of chance where there are plenty of choices but the only way to sieve out the better ones is to try a little from each dish. One great thing is that Cafe Brio stocks up quite a few dishes for each meat category, which increases the probability of success. Take of example in my favorite fish category, there is Deep Fried Sichuan Fish, Atlantic Butter Cod, Fish Otah, Stewed Fish Maw, etc. What took my fancy was the Pan Fried Sea Bass that sat in a pool of creamy mushroom, scattered with pomegranate seeds that complemented the savoury dish splendidly. Reason No. 4: OUTDOOR GRILL Adjourn to the outdoor grill section where one gets different kinds of marinated meats hot of the grill. We tried the thinly-sliced beef whose juices are duly retained. Some options like the pre-grilled items like pork fillets or lamp chops resided in the buffet warmer but I think it's still best to go for those freshly grilled items.Reason No. 5: FRENCH DESSERTSAttention gravitates towards the dessert counter, where a spread of tantalizing treats created by award-winning Executive Pastry Chef Nicolas Maugard who has honed his skills at several Michelin-star establishments over his 17 years of pastry career. This year's highlight is the Vanilla Pineapple Roasted Confit, Coconut Biscuit, Mango and Yuzu log cake.  Don't wrong the cake if you couldn't detect any crunch as the "Biscuit" is not literally the biscuit, but a dacquoise layer that is saturated with fragrant coconut shreds. Each segment had its own sea of significance but they seemed to bumped corners with another in what seemed to be an arbitrary assemblage. The Raspberry flavoured Grand Marnier and "Guanaja" Chocolate Christmas Yule Log Cake is a comfortable partnership of flavours but I wished the Grand Marnier flavour could be more pronounced. Nonetheless, the texture of the chocolate mousse is astoundingly velvety, just like the excellent Panna Cotta which I had previously at Pontini. Freshly made on the spot, the golden waffles with crisp browned edges and a tender, not-too-sweet interior is also worth a spot in the limited stomach space. Highly flexible to go along with any savoury ingredients like smoked salmon or sweet creamy ice cream.

address: 392 Havelock Road Grand Copthorne Waterfront Hotel lobby Singapore 169663 Singapore
comment: This place was the default option for the couple of days I stayed at the Grand Copthorne Waterfront Hotel.  Breakfast buffet was delicious.  Dinner buffet was still delicious.I ate too much every time but could not help myself since they had so many tasty options.  International variety was great too (Japanese,  Chinese, western, etc.).  One night they had teppanyaki and bbq served outside. Noms!Service was sometimes slow on the drinks but only once.  Other than that, great food for a hotel cafe.  I'm sure you'll find something you like.

address: 392 Havelock Road Grand Copthorne Waterfront Hotel lobby Singapore 169663 Singapore
comment: We had a cake from Grand Corpthorne, and it was pretty. It was the hotel's signature and bestseller, Chocolate Truffle, and we were all impressed the simple, yet pretty presentation and the taste. There was a shiny ganache layer, with artfully placed berries. Digging into cake revealed two moist sponge layers sandwiched between light light chocolate mousse. Raisins could be found within the layers as well, adding a variety of textures. There was also an alcohol tinge to the cake, not sure if the sponge had been presoaked with rum, but it complemented the cake nicely. However, as with most mousse cakes, too much will lead to one feeling rather stuffed, especially with a strong flavour like chocolate.

address: 392 Havelock Road Grand Copthorne Waterfront Hotel lobby Singapore 169663 Singapore
comment: The buffet dinner at Cafe Brio's is a truly international spread. There is local food such as satay outdoors, Japanese food, Western food and more depending on what is available on the day that you are there. I have been there a couple of times and am always glad for the choices. The food though is not exceptionally good but I think the hefty prices of $49 for Monday to Thursday nights and $59 for Friday to Sunday nights are paid mostly for the variety of dishes and ambience. One thing that is lacking though is the dessert options. There are perhaps about five choices and although the dessert changes from time to time, it is still quite limited.The ambience, as mentioned before, is the other thing you're paying for. The outdoor seating is near the river and makes for a serenely romantic backdrop for the evening, whether you are on a date or enjoying a meal with friends or family. In the cool evening breeze and the lovely setting, it is an ideal place to chat and eat a buffet meal slowly, in a relaxed fashion.

This is my virgin kaiseki and it was very memorable. Everything was so beautiful. It was like eating little pieces of art. There were a lot more courses than listed on the menu.The flavors were very simple but their freshness made them distinct. I'm not going to describe every course since it would take forever. Plus the menu changes with the season so every time is a new experience. Instead, I'll just focus on the few dishes that impressed me.The bonito smoke with hay was my favorite. Bonito is a strong fish. The smoke lends itself well to the bonito without overpowering and creates a different texture.The maguro was magnificent. We were given the otoro and akami . The otoro is an overrated cut of the tuna. The akami is by far my favorite because it has more flavor and a better texture. Chef Yoshiyuki agrees.The kinmedai was very elegant. It's a type of snapper but fattier and more flavorful than a regular red snapper. Grilling was the perfect treatment for the kinmedai.The entire meal was beautiful but these dishes were great. Will RTE if possible.

There are three options for lunch: we decided on the priciest $180++ omakase menu. The space is beautiful and quite dramatic. Softly lit too. Each course is beautifully and carefully prepared: we had yuba (delicate tofu skin) with uni and fresh wasabi, appetizer of lily root balls, smokey dashi clear soup with a beautiful white fleshed fish in it, flounder sashimi (Karei), toro sashimi with soya sauce foam (very molecular!) and cubes of akami, various grilled fish, one with rice like a nigiri sushi but sitting in a bowl of stock, and the filler dish of steamed rice and baby sardines and delicious pickles and soup. Dessert was a wafer like ice cream and as a birthday treat, Japanese fruits and a Sakura mochi were presented. Yoshiyuki-San was very polite and quite friendly. His other chef spoke better English and also engaged with guests. We enjoyed ourselves, and it was lovely to have a kaiseki meal so like the ones we had in Japan -- beautiful small dishes, carefully crafted reflecting the season (it's spring!) and showcasing pretty cutlery and tableware. A treat.

address: 1 Pasir Ris Central Street 3 #02-12/13/14, Pasir Ris White Sand Mall Singapore 518457 Singapore
comment: Cost: $$. Price in menu is inclusive of gst. Below were my review. Will definitely go back for the 4* & 5* dishes.--Crispy duck original c/w a set of Popiah skin (5*). Pay extra $3 for 2nd set of Popiah skin/cucumber/sauce. --Char siew Bao (4*). --Other dim sum ordered, don't have much impression.

address: 1 Pasir Ris Central St 3 #03-03 Singapore 518457 Singapore
comment: Came to visit this newly opened restaurant with my family on a Sunday night. It was only half filled and there were plenty of seats. Based on the waitress' recommendation we ordered both the Penang Fried Kway Teow and Penang Malay Style Mee Goreng. They both turned out pretty well. So well that I took a few bites and went "I need to Yelp this", hence, that photo of a half eaten plate. I've visited their outlet at terminal 3 before and surprisingly the food here seems a lot better! The only disappointment I have is that the portions can be larger for the price i paid. It was $8.95 for a portion that normally equates to the smallest portion a hawker serves (and that is normally between $3-4). Nevertheless, it was a good meal and I do appreciate the fact that they have tap water that's self service.

address: Pasir Ris MRT Station 10 Pasir Ris Central Singapore 519634 Singapore
comment: First off, I ant to say that e following dishes that I had is the Pasir Ris Ananas, not at this Outram Rd.I can't decide which noodle dish is better- the wanton mee (old fave) or dry fishball noodles. Both were so good, and I loved every mouthful. The wonton mee is soft and smooth, the sauce not too salty and the wonton nicely cooked. The generous vegetables were a big plus. The sambal does not have much kick, though.The fishball noodles were slightly less salty, and the fish balls are bigger than others I have eaten- very soft and not chewy at all. I'll have it again next time!Their chicken rice is oiler than I like, so paying some extra cents and worth it, though, is their char siew chicken rice. My god, it is fantastic. The slices were a lovely red colour and moist, going perfectly with the aromatic white rice. Don't eat with the chilli sauce! It overpowers. The soup is excellent, one of the best I've had.The you tiao is something I will not miss. It's just too oily to the point I feel lipsticked with oil. Generally, the fried items are not so bad.Dig in- don't be bothered if its too much oil or salt. Ananas is just another reason to enjoy hawker food while it lasts. :)
